prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
A Canadian diplomat has been arrested in Beijing, China, on suspicion of violating national security laws, the Chinese foreign ministry announced today.

The 40-year-old diplomat, identified as Marc Bergeron, was detained on April 15th while on a personal trip to visit his fiancée, a Chinese citizen.

Bergeron, who has been working at the Canadian embassy in Beijing since 2015, was accused of obtaining classified information without authorization.

The Chinese government claims that Bergeron's actions were a serious violation of Chinese law and pose a threat to national security.

Bergeron's family has denied the allegations, stating that he is innocent and was simply trying to help his fiancée's family with a business deal.

The Canadian government has demanded Bergeron's immediate release, calling the charges "baseless and politically motivated."

This is not the first time a Canadian has been detained in China. In 2018, businessman Michael Spavor was arrested on suspicion of espionage, and in 2020, journalist Amanda Chang was detained for allegedly stealing state secrets.

Both Spavor and Chang maintain their innocence, and the Canadian government has been working to secure their release.

A high-ranking official at the French embassy in Moscow has been taken into custody by Russian authorities on suspicion of espionage, the Kremlin announced earlier today.

The 38-year-old diplomat, identified as Sophie Dupont, was arrested on March 20th while attending a cultural event at the Russian capital's prestigious Bolshoi Theatre.

Dupont, who has been serving at the French embassy in Moscow since 2012, is accused of attempting to obtain classified documents related to Russia's military operations in Eastern Europe.

The Russian government claims that Dupont's actions constitute a grave threat to national security and are a clear violation of international law.

Dupont's colleagues at the embassy have denied the allegations, stating that she is innocent and was simply conducting research for a academic paper on Russian-French relations.

The French government has called for Dupont's immediate release, labeling the charges as "fabricated and politically motivated."

This is not the first time a French national has been detained in Russia. In 2019, businessman Pierre Leblanc was arrested on suspicion of embezzlement, and in 2021, journalist Marie Lefebvre was detained for allegedly spreading disinformation about the Russian government.

Both Leblanc and Lefebvre maintain their innocence, and the French government has been working to secure their release.

The 42-year-old diplomat, identified as Dr. Li Wei, was arrested on April 10th while attending a technology conference at the Tokyo International Forum.

Dr. Li, who has been serving at the Chinese consulate in Tokyo since 2015, is accused of attempting to steal sensitive information related to Japan's cutting-edge robotics industry.

The Japanese government claims that Dr. Li's actions constitute a serious threat to national economic security and are a clear violation of international trade agreements.

Dr. Li's colleagues at the consulate have denied the allegations, stating that he is innocent and was simply conducting research for a paper on Sino-Japanese economic cooperation.

The Chinese government has called for Dr. Li's immediate release, labeling the charges as "baseless and politically motivated."

This is not the first time a Chinese national has been detained in Japan. In 2018, businessman Wang Chen was arrested on suspicion of bribery, and in 2020, academic Dr. Zhang Jian was detained for allegedly stealing intellectual property.

Both Wang and Zhang maintain their innocence, and the Chinese government has been working to secure their release.

The 38-year-old officer, identified as Colonel Natalia Petrova, was arrested on March 25th while attending a cybersecurity conference at the Berlin Convention Center.
